subject: RE: [junit] Does this have a bad smell
msgSnippet: ... As I said it all depends on your need.  Eric has offered a potential framework in a vacuum devoid of context called an article.  That is what writers do.
messageBody:
> Well, yes, however to me it looks much more like a
> pattern for assertion
> testing than like a pattern for unit testing. If I had to
> unit test
> something like the controler, I would rather write own
> mock implementations
> of greeter and sender to test the controler: By doing so
> I will have no
> testing code in my production code. Does that seem too
> much of an overhead,
> or for what other reason is Eric Allen's approach more promising?

As I said it all depends on your need. Eric has offered a potential
framework in a vacuum devoid of context called an article. That is what
writers do. The quote at the top is probably what makes this smell bad to
you.

"Unit testing with JUnit can be a powerful way to ensure the integrity of
your code base, but some of the invariants are trickier to test than others
-- method-invocation sequence is one of them."

Take it with a grain of salt. If you find it is needed to test this way, go
ahead. But as you said, mock objects would *probably* be a better solution.

-Jason
